prop.head.headtext: Handling Cases Before the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation

prop.head.label.name: Chapter
prop.head.headtext: Effect of Transfer: Proceedings in the Transferee Court

head.headtext: Management of transferred cases—Pretrial conferences in complex litigation

para.paratext: Pretrial conferences have been held in virtually all federal court cases for years. The Federal Rules of Civil Procedure now require at least one pretrial scheduling conference to be held in every case.[1]

Pretrial conferences play an especially important role in management of complex cases. The Manual for Complex Litigation envisions a series of pretrial conferences.[2] These conferences have proven useful in management and in settlement of complex cases.[3]

One of the most important results of pretrial conferences in complex litigation is the entry of pretrial orders to govern the course of pretrial proceedings. These orders can extend to how the trial will be conducted in the event of remand, such as limiting the witnesses or number of witnesses to be called.[4] Pretrial orders can be very important tools in the management of cases, and have the status of other orders—they should be adhered to unless modified.[5]

One topic that is particularly important in complex cases relates to the joinder of parties. If new actions are filed in the federal courts, they are likely to be treated as tag-along actions and transferred pursuant to Panel Rules 7.1&7.2.[6] Where new parties or claims are introduced into the litigation, however, other issues are raised, and these events may disrupt the course of the case. It is for this reason that it is quite important in all complex cases, particularly in MDL transfer dockets, that the court consider implementing a deadline for joining additional parties and for amending to add new issues to the case.[7] In addition to the case-management ramifications of new claims or parties, it may be appropriate to defer granting dispositive relief until “the bidding is closed” on adding claims or parties to the case.[8]
Maslon Edelman Borman & Brand, LLP, Minneapolis, Minnesota.
See Manual for Complex Litigation Fourth § 11.2 (2004).
See William W Schwarzer, Managing Antitrust and Other Complex Litigation§§ 6-1 to 6-3 (1982).
See, e.g., In re Factor VIII or IX Concentrate Blood Products Litigation, 169 F.R.D. 632, 636 (N.D. Ill. 1996) (transferee court can enter order limited number of expert witnesses at trial).

See, e.g., In re Phenylpropanolamine (PPA) Products Liability Litigation, 460 F.3d 1217 (9th Cir. 2006) (court did not abuse discretion in dismissing actions for failure to comply with case management orders).
Tag-along actions are discussed in ch. 8, supra.
See generally Manual for Complex Litigation (Fourth) § 11.32 (2004).

See, e.g., Teamster Local Union No. 714 v. GES Exposition Services, Inc., 494 F. Supp. 2d 970, 973 (N.D. Ill. 2007) (summary judgment raises potential joinder issues that should be resolved before deciding merits of summary judgment motion).
